I'm staying from today, so I'm not sure if this answer will be in time, but I will answer.
I have stayed at this hotel many times, and most recently, my last stay was in 2019.
It's been almost 15 years since it opened, but it's been well maintained and has the same high-class feel as when it first opened, and I personally think it's beautiful.
Since it is located in Sengokuhara, it has a calmer impression compared to Hakone Yumoto. Since it is possible to go by car, I think that access to the surrounding tourist facilities is not a problem.
I don't know if the park is open at this time of year, but the Hakone Botanical Garden is right next door. When I went in June, the flowers were in bloom and it was beautiful.
For dinner, we recommend eating at a restaurant nearby rather than at the hotel. There are Unaju shops and Italian restaurants where pizza is delicious.
The shop is more complete than other Harvest facilities, so you won't have any trouble choosing souvenirs at the shop. Also, I forgot the name of the restaurant, but I remember that there was a delicious steamed bun restaurant nearby.

column6:
Wherever I go, I think the park on Sunday is crowded now, but here are three places that seem to be few.

[1] Educational Forest Park → Senshunen
A park near Myogadani , where neighbors come to play with their children.
In particular, Senshunen in the back is a little careless, but it is a park full of nature, and it is a forest where Japanese pygmy woodpeckers and long-tailed tit rest their feathers.
The cherry blossoms are gathered from the university dormitory to the open space below, and bloom beautifully.
There are many famous spots in the neighborhood, Harimazaka Sakura-lined trees, but since it is located uphill and famous Japanese sweets shops are also located below,
people who come to see the cherry blossoms from other places I don't think you can come here very often.
I think it is a fairly minor spot for cherry blossom viewing.

[2] Shin-Otsuka side Minami-Otsuka 3-chome Sakura-lined street
This is Minami-Otsuka, and the station side seems to have a decent name, but the cherry blossom trees continue for a long time from the front of Otsuka station.
Avoid the Otsuka station side where there are events, etc., and access from Shin-Otsuka station.

The downhill from Nishisugamo Junior High School to Platanus Street (Famima's corner) is completely in a residential area, so almost no people flow.
The rows of trees lined up on both sides are quite good, but there aren't many restaurants in the neighborhood, and there aren't many restaurants in the neighborhood, so even if you try to eat and drink outside, you can't go through the streets, but you can only see the flowers, so the risk is low.

[3] Waseda Toyohashi
There is a row of Kanda River cherry blossom trees from Edogawabashi Station to Edogawa Park to Higo Hosokawa Garden, which is a famous place for cherry blossoms, and it is a continuation of it.
There are many people there, so if you want to avoid the crowds, don't stop by even if you make a mistake. If possible, you should avoid Edogawabashi Station and Takadanobaba Station, which is used by many people.
The row of cherry blossom trees on the Kanda River continues all the way to Takadanobaba, and is just a short walk from Waseda Station on the Toden-Arakawa Line and Toei Bus Ii 64 Grand Sakashita.
When you come to the vicinity of Toyohashi, which is just right, you can see the scenery of cherry blossoms lined up on both sides of the river, even though the number of people who bother to stop by is greatly reduced.
Some people secretly set up their cameras to take pictures of the cherry blossoms.
The cherry blossoms on both sides of the bridge are always splendid, so I can assure you that the cherry blossoms from Toyohashi will shine. In addition, there is a small park called Yamabuki no Sato Park, which is a little far from the river. It's a deep place, so only neighbors come first.
There is Daiei in the neighborhood, benches and toilets in the park, and a bakery called Kandagawa Bakery opposite, so you can take a break outdoors without getting too crowded.

What do you think. Please check the state of the flowers on Google.

Aer Observation Terrace is good around Sendai Station, but I personally recommend SS30 (Sumitomo Life Sendai Central Building) if you want to see the night view.
The stained glass inside Sendai Station is famous as a meeting spot, but if you take a closer look, it will be very beautiful.
In Sendai station gourmet, in addition to Ushitan-dori, Zunda-dori and Zunda-charo, which is famous for Zunda Shake, are famous.
Sendai station square-Ichibancho-Kokubuncho is in the center of Sendai, but it is connected by an arcade and it is fun just to walk slowly.
The gourd fried at Abe Gamo store is also famous as a friend of eating.
I personally recommend it at the restaurant, but there is a meat restaurant called "Bisutorohei" near Sendai Station where you can enjoy Sendai beef, which is very delicious.
Also, "Ando" in Ichibancho is a creative restaurant, and I think you can relax by yourself, and this is also delicious.
It's been a long time since I left Sendai, but due to the redevelopment after the earthquake, the area around Sendai Station has been reborn as a very fashionable spot, and many delicious shops have been opened.
As I was writing, I also wanted to go.
Eat lots of delicious food and make your trip enjoyable.

column6:
Hello.

When it comes to the deliciousness of Shimane, first of all, soba. In addition, the white squid (sashimi) fried at Sakaiminato in the western part of Tottori, which has almost the same living area, is delicious, but that is only for summer, so it's a shame.
There are 50,000 shops for the soba. Among them, I will list the places that I was really happy to eat.
Matsue: Funatsu (raw flour), Kamiyo.
Yakumo-an is famous, but it falls a little (but it's enough). But the atmosphere is outstanding.
Izumo: Kanaya, Arakiya.
Okuizumo: Asahitei, Hachikawa soba (with delicious rice balls from Nita rice), demon soba.
(Tottori) Yonago: Kamidai, Shoan.
Lake Shinji is also famous for its freshwater clams, but no matter when you go to the Shijimikan, you won't find any large raw clams.
Rather, the clear white fish in the dining room called Fukukichi on the northern lakeside was delicious. It seems that there are some natural eels from Lake Shinji.
In addition, my wife says that Minami Matsue's sea bream chazuke (sea bream?) Is exquisite.
Sushi went to some decent sushi restaurants, and although it wasn't bad, there weren't many kinds of sushi, and he was frustrated. According to him, most of the good fish go to Tokyo.
For dessert, why not try Kiyomizu-dera, which is located in front of the gate of Kiyomizu-dera, which is famous for its triple tower near the mountains of Yasugi. Very normal, but not bad.

That's my poor experience. There can be a lot of differences in taste, so it's just a light reference.

Then, please make a good trip in late autumn.

Ikuchijima has almost flat coastline roads, so it's easy to ride a bicycle. Omishima has some ups and downs on the coastline road, so the uphill may be a little difficult (I will borrow an electric assist if I go next time), but the scenery is better on Omishima.

column6:
Hello.
Previously, I tried to go around Tsushima in one day and couldn't go around at all (it ended only south of Watatsumi Shrine / Karasuhatake), so I went to revenge in 2 days and 1 night.

Tsushima has many ups and downs, and it takes longer to move than you can imagine by looking at a flat map.
As you mentioned, the Korean observatory located on the north side and the hill observatory where you can see foreign countries are quite far, so I think it is difficult to go around in one day.
You said that you have 2 nights and 3 days. What are you going to do on the 1st and 3rd days?
I think it's better to rent a car in full, or have a car for at least two days.

For lunch, there aren't many restaurants other than Izuhara, and I remember going to Izuhara for a meal.

Is it a ferry or an airplane? Which is your stay?
I think that the route will change a little depending on that, but since Izuhara Port and the airport are on the south side, I think that you should go around in order so as to connect the places you want to go with a line.

Tsushima has a long history and nature, so it is a very interesting place.
Banshoin Temple, Mongol Invasion Beach, Miuda Beach, and Shiine's stone roof warehouse are also beautiful and interesting.
Have a nice trip
column7: Tsushima sightseeing

column6:
nice to meet you. I made a trip to Miyazaki in early April this year. I went from Haneda to and from Miyazaki Airport. I traveled from the north of Miyazaki prefecture to the south of Miyazaki prefecture in 2 days and 1 night, but the first flight was the first flight and the last flight was the return flight, so the trip was on a fairly tight schedule.

It depends on where you are going to visit, but I will introduce the routes I visited in April for reference.

Head north from Miyazaki Airport to the sea station, and tour the horseback, the sea of Cruz, and Kunimigaoka. However, it was raining heavily on the day I went, so I was almost in a glimpse of everything. If it was sunny, I was planning to stay until the evening and see the sunset in the sea of Cruz, but I realized that I couldn't do that, so in the afternoon I just drove to Miyazaki city again, and a shop slightly outside Miyazaki city. I ate dinner at. I stayed in the center of Miyazaki city.

The next day, I left the hotel after 8 am, and this time I went south to Cape Toi, Udo Shrine, Nichinan Sunmesse, and Sekinoo Waterfall for lunch near Sunmesse. I was planning to go to Horikiri Pass and Aoshima Shrine, but I didn't have time to cut it. On the second day, it rained heavily in the morning and I had to go to Cape Toi in the fog, so I couldn't see a good view, but I think it would be a great place if it was sunny. There are wild horses that cross the road normally. You need to be careful when driving, but there are promenades and lighthouses. Udo Shrine was also on a precipitous cliff, and it was quite spectacular. Sekinoo Waterfall is located near Kagoshima. There were few tourists in a slightly minor place, but you can see a fairly powerful waterfall from the suspension bridge.
By the way, at Sunmesse Nichinan, I didn't have much time to see the Moai statue, and the staying time was about 10 minutes.

If you have the energy to drive for a long time, you can go all the way from north to south, but if you only have one, I think the south is recommended in terms of sightseeing spots.
You can drive while looking at the sea in both the north and the south, but I feel that you can see the sea from a higher place in the north.

I also wrote reviews of the restaurant where I ate, so please see the page if you like.
column7: Drive along the coast of Miyazaki prefecture (north or south of Miyazaki prefecture)

column6:
Hello again.

I'm staying in Amakusa, but I often hang around in front of Kumamoto station.
You can use the round-trip Shinkansen from your house, but during the busy seasons such as New Year's holidays, Golden Week, and Bon Festival, the Shinkansen and the aisles are full of people, so you may return by using an airplane with a limited number of passengers. I left my acquaintance's house in Amakusa in the morning and went to Kumamoto station in the afternoon. I take the airport limousine bus from Kumamoto station around 15:00, but the road is not crowded during the busy season mentioned above. With that in mind, when I flew home on weekdays, the road was congested and I was impatient. .. .. I ran on the bus lane in the city, so I went to the airport safely without much delay.

The airport limousine bus has copied the timetable before, but the bus that stops at Kumamoto Station goes to Sakuramachi Bus Terminal.

column6:
Hello.

You may get an answer with another person.

Awao chicken in Tokushima prefecture is a brand name of chicken, and unlike general tender chicken that is shipped in about 50 days, this Awao chicken is a local chicken that is shipped in about 80 days. increase.
Since local chickens have been bred for a long time, they have elastic and satisfying meat quality.
By the way, I don't like this rubber-like texture, so I don't eat much even if the local chicken is a specialty at my travel destination.

Kagawa Prefecture's bone-in chicken is not a chicken brand, but a dish name, so you should check whether or not you will wear it because you do not know which chicken the restaurant uses.


If you go to Shikoku and eat chicken, Awao chicken is also famous, but we recommend Shimanto chicken, a brand chicken from Kochi prefecture.
Since this Shimanto chicken is a young chicken, the meat is tender and has a very fluffy texture.
At my hometown, I pay my hometown tax, and I receive this Shimanto chicken as a thank-you item for 4 kg every month on a regular flight.

Of course, bonito is famous in Kochi prefecture, but the bonito season is spring and autumn.
Besides bonito, tuna and Thai are also very delicious.
Tuna is sometimes given as a hometown tax refund, but it is no different from the famous places in other prefectures.


The answer was a little off, but I hope it helps.
I wish you a good trip.

Please be careful about traffic safety and have a fun trip.

column7: Is it difficult to walk from Kita-Kamakura to Zeniarai Benzaiten?

column6:
I have walked from Kita-Kamakura Station to Zeniarai Benten, Hase Daibutsu, and Enoden, but it is not a big "mountain". In the afternoon of the day, I went to Enoshima by Enoden and walked around the Enoshima Aquarium and Enoshima Island.

The mountains surrounding the city of Kamakura are also commonly referred to as the "Kamakura Alps", but is the highest altitude of this course around 160m?

The signposts are solid, and there are many roads that go down to the city on the way.

However, it is not a rainy day, a day after rain, or a day of frost columns, but the road is dry, non-slippery, and you are wearing solid shoes.
A few years ago, heavy rains destroyed the road and closed it for a long time.

It is out of the question to carry luggage in your hand, so carry it on your back with a backpack and leave both hands free.

Also, if you are traveling with an infant, consider the distance and speed based on the weakest person.

If you are an adult male, I don't think it will be a course that feels "close to mountain climbing."

column6:
Hello.

I'm not a local, but when I lived in the metropolitan area before, I often went on business trips to Mito city, so I will answer as much as I can understand.

＞ Bus 1-day pass 400 yen
＞ Not all route maps are shown on the bus company's web ...

Mito Manyu 1-day free ticket
http://www.ibako.co.jp/regular/ticket/mito-free.html

Mito Manyu 1-day free ticket application route map
http://www.ibako.co.jp/Images/manyu-2019_map.png

By the way, the fare between Mito Station and Korakuen on the bus is 240 yen, so Mito Manyu 1-day free ticket The use is certainly profitable.

＞ Bus 400 yen and rental bicycle 500 yen If the

weather is not bad, the rental cycle is more flexible, but as the previous respondent said, there are some undulations in the city (the central area of the downtown area is slightly higher).

Kairakuen is the most convenient place to use the Kairakuen bus stop when using the bus, but since there is no nearest bus stop at Ibarakiagatama Shrine (Sakurayama bus stop if you use it forcibly), go after sightseeing in Kairakuen. Or vice versa, but it is convenient to have a rental cycle because there is a reasonable distance between them and the Kairakuen area is vast.

> 2km or more ... It

means going from Mito station at the distance of Kairakuen from Mito station, right? ??
If so, it depends on the route, but the shortest is certainly 2km.

By bus, it takes about 15 minutes from Mito Station North Exit Bus Stop to Kairakuen Bus Stop.

My personal conclusion is that if the weather is good and the temperature is good for the questioner, it is better to rent a bicycle, and if the weather is not good and the temperature is low, it is better to use the bus.

However, Kairakuen is a vast garden, so depending on the area you are watching, I think you can walk quite a bit here alone.

Again, it depends on the waves.

Tokyo metropolitan area, but my specialty of day trips is to get on the highway before 4 o'clock and return home in the bright light.

By this time, it will be bright enough at 4 o'clock and bright until about 19:00, so it is safe to drive. Another advantage is that there is no traffic jam on the outbound route.

In addition, you can use a 30% discount at midnight on the expressway (including around Tokyo).
The highway fee will not be stupid when it gets far away. (In the old days, it was a 50% discount.)

Then there are 15 hours, and if you are in the field for 4 hours, you will have 5 and a half hours one way.

For example, if you go to Hakone, if you leave the Sendai Minami IC at 4 o'clock in Navitime, it will take just over 5 hours to reach Hakone Sengokuhara. I think it's quite possible if you can minimize your breaks or return home after 19:00.
Hakone is best if the tourist facilities are compact and sunny.

column7: About sightseeing time

column6:
＞＞ I would be grateful if you could give me some advice as to when it is actually better.

I live in the Tokyo metropolitan area and sometimes drive in the Tohoku region, but if you are visiting the sea for sightseeing in Oshima, I think you should avoid it in winter.
There will be little snow in the plains.

If it's sunny, the monsoon is strong, and if it's cloudy, it's a landscape different from the bright image of the sea. It would be the worst if it rained even in the miso.

In winter, there is an advantage that inns and sightseeing spots are vacant, but when it comes to
outdoor location tours, there is likely to be freezing in the morning, such as at the top of forest roads.

Also, around December, the dusk is early and tourist time tends to be closed.

After the equinoctial week in March, it would be better if the cherry blossoms bloomed in April, if possible.

column6:
Some things I noticed.

The best time to see the roses in Higashizawa Rose Garden is the end of September, so the
roses aren't blooming when you go.
For the time being, there is a lake and it is also called Higashizawa Park, so
you can go sightseeing as a park without roses.

The bus to Zao is late at 13:30.
The bus is probably the one used by the guests.
The ropeway is about once every 20 minutes, and it ends at 16:30 in November, and
it is dim and cold by that time.
The peak was around 17 degrees Celsius even in summer, so it
may be below 10 degrees Celsius in early November, and it gets quite cold when it gets dark at sunset.
If possible, it is desirable to depart by 12:00 at Yamagata Station.

Is this a round-trip ticket with a Zao ropeway ticket?
http://www.yamakobus.co.jp/new/20210619zaoset.html
There is a departure from Yamagata Station without going to Yamagata Airport.

If Zao also goes by bus around Yamagata, you
may not need a rental car?
You can walk to Higashizawa Park in Murayama with
JR, and you can also go to Yamadera, Tendo, and Kaminoyama Onsen by JR.

After all, it is convenient to have a rental car only in the Matsushima / Akiho area, so
it
may be enough to use the rental car for one day only on the third day (even one day is possible) .

Matsushima and Akiu also take time, but you can go by JR or bus.
I have never used Sendai Airport (JR only)
, but it seems that the high-speed train is faster than the car at Sendai Station.

Between Sendai over Yamagata, so go with the high-speed bus or Senzan Line,
1 day, out of the Airport to Sendai Station, up to Yamagata at JR or high-speed bus
to go,
that day in the tourist Yamagata, the second day a day full
Isn't it good for sightseeing in Zao ? I think.
Zao also depends on the weather, and if the weather is bad, I
wonder if I should stop the ropeway and use only hot springs in half a day.

Afternoon tea at The Westin Hotel was
good around Sendai Station .
I went there in 2010 when the hotel was built, but the
afternoon tea was on the 26th floor and the view was good.

The name of the afternoon tea shop has changed, and the
content is different from 2010, but now
it feels like Shine Muscat and the content have been upgraded.
Afternoon tea is 3880 yen (tax and service charge included) on weekdays.
If you make a WEB reservation from the website below, you will get 10% off at 3492 yen (tax and service charge included).
https://www.the-westin-sendai.com/rest/sym/sweet_sansation/ If you make a
reservation from the website, you can make a reservation with champagne or by the window (no 10% off).
There are options such as with parfait. In
addition, we recommend Zunda Mochi and Zunda Shake at Zunda Saryo in Sendai.
Sightseeing in Sendai city is rude, but there are few things to see, and half a day is enough.
Sendai Castle Ruins Park, Zuihoden, Osaki Hachimangu Shrine (shrine).

If I can take half a day on the last day, is that enough?
On the 4th day,
why not take the Shinkansen to Ichinoseki and go to Geibikei, Genbikei, and Hiraizumi ?
Rent-a-car is more convenient, but you can also go by bus.
I used the bus.
I think the autumn leaves are good in early November.

column3: Widely considered to be one ... Op 's
column6:
When the corona settles down, I plan to travel to Hiraizumi, a hot spring town in Hanamaki, Iwate Prefecture.
We are planning to visit the hot spring town in Hanamaki and Chusonji in Hiraizumi, but we are planning to go south from Morioka and stay in Sendai without using a car as a route.

I'm thinking of moving from Morioka to Hanamaki for one night, then moving to Hiraizumi the next day to see Chusonji etc., but Hiraizumi is starting to think that it may be possible to move to Sendai as it is after sightseeing without staying overnight.

I'm not good at rushing, but if you need to stay overnight in Hiraizumi, or if you are traveling or living in this area and have some experiences, I would be grateful if you could give me some advice.
column7: When staying at Hanamaki and Hiraizumi for one night each.

column6:
Hanamaki accommodation, of course, I think it's a hot spring. I don't know the means of transportation, but if you choose the lead hot springs and Osawa hot springs in Minami Hanamaki, which have the atmosphere of a hot spring resort, it will take a long time to get to Hanamaki station. There should be a free bus to the station.

Hanamaki Onsen is good as it is, but it is hard to throw away Dai Onsen, which is mainly a small inn in the back.

By the way, Hiraizumi, as many people have written it, I will avoid duplication, but I recommend Tatsuya Cave and Honederamura Ruins. Genbikei Gorge on the way is known for its valley beauty.


Ichinoseki is recommended for accommodation. It's worth staying just to visit the world-famous jazz cafe Basie, but the brewery restaurant Sekinoichi no Mochi cuisine is very famous, and the brewery is also a small museum.

The castle town of the Tamura clan was lost due to the flood, but when you look for it, some samurai residences remain and are open to the public.

The next morning, you can go to Geibikei on the Ofunato Line. Also, if you get off at Matsukawa, which is just before you, you will find a museum related to Kenji. This is because Kenji has worked as an engineer at the old crushed stone factory here.

Even if you stay overnight, you will not be in trouble the next day.
column7: When staying at Hanamaki and Hiraizumi for one night each.

column6:
Hello, Mr.

Hammer Clavier, in December of last year, at the four temples of Michinoku's old temple pilgrimage "Shiji Corridor", Zuiganji Temple in Matsushima, which was opened by Jikaku Daishi Ennin, Risshakuji Temple in Yamadera, Chusonji Temple in Hiraizumi and Motsuji Temple. Then, I went to Miyagi, Yamagata, and Iwate for a four-night, five-day trip with the theme of following the back alley that Basho Matsuo visited.
In Iwate, I stayed at Hiraizumi and Ichinoseki, so I will write down various thoughts at that time for your reference.

First of all, Hiraizumi is a tour of historic sites and temples related to World Heritage Sites.
I think it is common to go around Motsuji Temple (Kanjizaiōin Ruins) -Hiraizumi Cultural Heritage Center-Chusonji Temple-Takadachi Gikeido-Mugenkouin Ruins.
Starting from JR Hiraizumi Station, it is about 7 to 8 kilometers, so you can walk around for a day.
According to the research at that time, I found that I could rent a car, rent a bicycle, or take a bus, but I decided to rent a car because I wanted to go to Geibikei, Genbikei, Takkoku Saikoji, and Ichinoseki's prestigious jazz cafe Basie.
If you can't drive, you can walk or rent a bicycle if you have enough physical strength, or if it's tight, you can go around the Hiraizumi patrol bus.
There is certainly a bicycle rental shop with electric assist in front of Hiraizumi station.
Runrun goes around all the above major spots, but please be careful about the operating days.
* For reference, http://iwatekenkotsu.co.jp/runrun_0419.html

Regarding accommodation, there are few inns and shops in Hiraizumi.
I used to stay at a hot spring inn in Hiraizumi for one night, but if you want to enjoy hot springs in Hanamaki, it might be better to go to Sendai or Ichinoseki.

Since the signs of the 4th wave of corona are seen in Miyagi prefecture, it is difficult to choose the time, but I think that you can have a fun trip with world heritage sites, hot springs, gourmet food!
column7: When staying at Hanamaki and Hiraizumi for one night each.

column6:
Hello Hammer Clavier. My name is Passion K.

Whether to stay overnight in
Hiraizumi 1. Where to visit in Hiraizumi?
2. Whether or not to make a schedule after arriving in Sendai 3. The question is
what time to leave Hanamaki Onsen in connection with No. 1
.

In particular, Hiraizumi is famous for Chusonji Temple, but there are so many other attractions that it is important to choose whether to see it or not.

When I visited Hiraizumi in 2018, my primary purpose was to see all the remains of Iwate Prefecture, which is a World Heritage Site and is currently aiming to be added to the World Heritage Site, so it is contrary to Hammer Clavier's plan. I made Hanamaki a passing point, but the course is similar, so for reference below. (I will attach the URL of my travelogue. Please refer to it.) The

schedule is

Day 1 Tokyo Station → Tono Station → (Rentaka) → World Heritage Hashino blast furnace ruins → (Rentaka) → Tono Station → Ichinoseki Station → (Rentaka) → World Heritage Mogoshiji Temple → World Heritage Site of the Royal Palace Hiraizumi Tomari
https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11415516
https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11415529
Day 2 (All-day rental car) Hiraizumi Cultural Heritage Center → World Heritage Chusonji Temple → Shiratori Tate Ruins → Chojagahara Abandoned Temple Ruins → Honedera Village Shoen Ruins → Tatsuya Cave Bishamondo → Yanagi no Gosho Ruins → World Heritage Mugen Koin Ruins Hiraizumi Tomari
https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11415533 https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11415533
https //4travel.jp/travelogue/11415546
Day 3 World Heritage Kinkeizan Climbing → (Rentaka) → Takadachi Gikeido → (Rentaka) → Ichinoseki Station → Tokyo
https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11415549

I stayed at Hiraizumi for 2 nights. I rented a car because the assets I am aiming to register as a World Heritage Site are in the suburbs where buses are rarely running.
However, Chusonji Temple and Motsuji Temple are in the city and can be reached by bus, and I don't think it costs much by taxi.

If you plan to visit only Chusonji Temple in Hiraizumi, it takes just over 2 hours to visit Chusonji Temple, and it takes 30-40 minutes by bus or taxi from the station, so you don't have to stay in Hiraizumi. It's okay if you look at Motsuji Temple for an hour.

Hiraizumi is a tourist destination with many attractions, so the time required for Hiraizumi will change depending on what you see and what you don't see, and you will naturally decide whether or not to stay.
Hiraizumi also has Hiraizumi hot springs, and you can put them in the hot springs, so it might be good to squeeze the hot springs from Hanamaki hot springs!

Hello.

As you say, it's still cold ~
Nagano is in the ski season until the end of March, so there is a lot of snow at the ski resorts ...
At this time, it's a hot spring except for winter sports ~
(I'm sorry I'm not familiar with hot springs)

When I think of Tateshina, it's not just the "Tateshinakogen Barakura English Garden"
roses. Christmas roses and bulbs are in bloom around March. The entrance fee is set cheaper than in the high season, and some days are free. For more information ↓

Tateshina Kogen Barakura English Garden ⇒ https://barakura.co.jp/about

Then there is a strange

"Tateshina Amusement Aquarium" in the mountains with only freshwater fish ⇒ https://www.tateshina-aquarium. jp /

Also,

"Mishakaike" drawn by Kaii Higashiyama ⇒ https://navi.chinotabi.jp/spot/3076/

I think that Mishakaike is beautiful in early summer and autumn leaves, but on a cold day There seems to be a day when you can see a beautiful white landscape. (Spots that are only recommended for private cars because of poor access)

If you come to Tateshina on the highway, you will probably get off at the "Suwa Interchange", but there is Suwa Taisha Shrine nearby. The lower shrine is on the opposite side of Lake Suwa, and there are four "Suwa Taisha" companies, so it may be good to go around all of them. (It's a power spot)

March in Shinshu is still cold, but when the weather is nice, the contrast between the clear blue sky and the pure white snowy mountains is the best (I personally think that the blue sky in early spring is the most beautiful). But I think you can enjoy it.

Mr. Mita does not say, "A surveillance camera is attached to all ICs in Nagano prefecture to monitor other prefecture numbers"! Do you monitor and turn back?
Most ICs nationwide are equipped with surveillance cameras (to see traffic conditions, etc.)!

Certainly, when I went to "Barakura" on Prefectural Day last fall, there were many foreign cars (Kanto) in Tateshinakogen, probably because there are many villas, even though I was warned about moving across prefectures. It was. (Same for Karuizawa)
Sometimes infected people come out from this villa family (counted in Nagano and hospitalization is also Nagano), and even though children in Nagano such as university students who are going to the metropolitan area can not go home, from outside the prefecture Some harsh opinions are heard when there are people who can come.
However, since it is a tourist prefecture, there are many places waiting for tourists to take measures against infection. Please go out when the state of emergency is lifted.

I don't think the trip will be the same as before even if vaccination starts, but let's enjoy it as it is!
For your reference ... Have a good trip!

Hello In

mid-March, it's still winter in the area.
Be sure to protect yourself from the cold.
Is ... to be considered in the sights of this period

and North Yatsugatake ropeway

is good car window of the landscape. You can see the Yatsugatake mountain range and Mt. Ontake from a distance.
It might be a good idea to walk "Tsuboba" from the mountaintop station. It's just a perfect snowy road, so it's safer to have something like snow spikes. A short walk will bring you to a mountain lodge (Shimagare Sansou) with a blue triangular roof, where you can take a break with a hot drink. The scenery from this area is also very beautiful.

・ Megami

Lake It is a small lake that freezes completely in the middle of winter, but the scenery with the mountains in the background is beautiful. On weekdays, the shop may be closed. If that happens, I will die (laughs)

・ Lake Tateshina

Like Megami Lake, it is a very small lake (pond). There is no such thing as this in winter, but it seems that the roadside station opened last summer. It might be a good idea to stop by after a break.

・ Yokotani Gorge The

road surface may still be frozen in March, so snow spikes are essential.
There are few people on the promenade along the river, and you can see stunning icicles on the opposite bank (although the timing is terrible). At the entrance of Yokotanikyo, "Maiden Falls" has frozen droplets, and you can see the scenery unique to winter. If you can walk to Yokotani Kannon, the view from there is quite spectacular.

・ Sekiseki Ruins Jomon Archaeological Museum The

area is close to Chino City, but it doesn't seem to be very popular (laughs).

・ Tateshina Free Farm

This is also a direct sales office like a roadside station in an area near Chino city. There are a wide variety of products and processed products, so it is a facility that can be used for home use and as souvenirs.

As mentioned above, I'm sorry for the old information, but I hope it helps.
In addition, my actual experience was before the Corona disaster, so the situation may have changed now. note that.

There is no place like a tourist spot on the forest road in the back from Hotaka Onsen, and I remember that I was just concerned about driving on bad roads.
I think it's a trip by car, so please be careful as it may be after heavy rain.

I don't really understand the part that says, "On the way back from Azumino, Matsumoto, Suwa, Kiso, and Kaida Kogen."
Nakabusa Onsen is at the back of a clogged road, and if you don't come back near Hotaka Station, there is no way back.

This summer has a lot of bad weather, so don't decide to go sightseeing the next day. We recommend that you plan flexibly, such as "Azumino Sightseeing Daio Wasabi Farm (reference URL)".

Only when the weather is nice, instead of "Kaida Kogen passing through Kiso", avoid going through Matsumoto and Shiojiri, which are likely to be crowded on holidays. but if the weather isn't bad, the best time to see it is around the 6th.
However, probably because of the high temperature this year, it is difficult because there are many places in the northeastern part of Kanto and around Fukushima where it is early to bloom after flowering.
After all, no matter how full bloom the cherry blossoms are, they don't look beautiful on a cloudy day, so you can't know the best timing until just before.
column7: I want to know the best flowering time of the cherry blossoms on Mt. Kobo

column6:
The cherry blossoms in the metropolitan area are already in the final stages. I went to Kamakura yesterday, and although it was in full bloom, it had already begun to disperse.
According to Sakura ch information, Mt. Kobo is in full bloom on the 29th. In my experience, Yoshino cherry trees often start to fall on the 4th day after full bloom, so I try to choose a sunny day from full bloom to the 3rd day as much as possible.

The best of Koboyama will be today. The weather is also good. It is a famous place over a wide area, and depending on various conditions such as wind, the best time to see it may continue until the 3rd, but the weather seems to be bad on the 6th, so I think it is close to no chance.

column6:
I like mountains, so in the fall, aiming for a sunny day when mobile high pressure comes, I skipped the central highway at midnight and entered the Ogisawa parking lot, aimed at Murodo with the first bus connection in the morning, and climbed Mt. Tsurugi round trip during the day. From my experience

The second reason is that the Shimanami Kaido is more enjoyable to cross by car than to pass by bus because you can get closer to the island on the way.

The third reason is that the same rental car has less driving risk and stress.
If you drive various cars on a regular basis, the stress may be small, but I am not good at changing lever operations and navigation operations.

There are many limited express buses between Matsuyama and Kochi, so if you rent a bus near Kochi Station and return it at Kochi Airport, it will be cheaper than renting in Ehime Prefecture.

column6:
Snake, nice to meet you. My name is Shima.

Although it is in category (3), one point is missing from your answers.

He said he was going out for the first week of June. It's about time for the rainy season. The seasons are fast this year, so it may be raining.

Koyasan in the rain is also nice, but please be prepared for your feet. I think it's a good idea to have shoes that are resistant to rain, slippery, and dirty.
You will have to walk a reasonable distance to Okunoin, and there are many bumps on the paving stones, making it slippery. Due to the terrain, Koyasan is prone to heavy rain, so if you have a good rain forecast, it is safe to change your socks and stockings.

On the contrary, be careful of the temperature rise when it is sunny. There are many shades of trees, but it is a place with high humidity, so it is necessary to prepare for heat stroke. We recommend that you carry a hat, parasol and drinks.

If you have a relaxed attitude, you will be able to get away from the world and feel the atmosphere of the sacred place more, without turning around like a normal tourist spot.

Have a nice trip ♪
column7: Efficient way to turn

column6:
Hebio-san
You go to Nara during the cherry blossom season!
Sounds good! !!

There are other famous places such as Koriyama Castle, Takadagawa, Matabei Sakura, etc., but I will answer about the places I have been to.

①
Along the Saho River ... Cherry blossoms are planted for many kilometers. I think it is convenient to access because it is close to the center of Nara.

Mt. Mimuro ... It's in Ikaruga, and it's about the size of a hill rather than a mountain, but it was wonderful because the entire mountain was covered with cherry blossoms. Cherry blossoms were also planted along the Tatsuta River until I got there, and it was fun to walk because the locals had a small banquet with their neighbors.
It's not flashy at all, but I liked the laid-back atmosphere of Nara.

②
Hasedera ... Needless to say, it is a flower temple.

Himuro Shrine ... The weeping cherry blossoms are amazing right next to Nara Park, but when I visited there a few years ago, I was lonely because the cherry blossoms got sick. I'm not sure about the situation this year, so I would appreciate it if you could check in advance.
It is a convenient place to see the cherry blossoms around Todaiji Temple, Nara Park, and Ukimido.

Oomiwa Shrine ... Weeping cherry blossoms are also beautiful here, so if you like weeping cherry blossoms, we recommend it.

Ishibutai Tumulus ... I like the laid-back scenery of the stone stage and Asuka and the cherry blossoms.

Chogosonshiji Temple ... You can see the cherry blossoms from a high place and it wasn't crowded when I went, so it might be good if you want to relax.

③ The best time to see the cherry blossoms in Yoshino is slightly different, such as upper thousand, middle thousand, and lower thousand, but I think it is still a little early at the end of March. It depends on changes in temperature, so you may see it if it blooms earlier than usual.

It would be nice if the weather was nice and you could see the beautiful cherry blossoms!

order is Shirahama → Kushimoto → Katsuura → Hongu (Yu no Mine).
● For Shirahama Onsen ① Saki-no-Yu (the sea and the hot spring are connected) ② Tsuna-no-Yu (It is a public bath, but the quality of the hot spring is excellent) For
sightseeing ① Sandanbeki ② Senjojiki ③ Engetsu Island?
If you are staying at a hotel, you should search the internet for an inn where you can eat que (fish) and stay there.
● There is Kushimoto Onsen, but we do not recommend it.
For sightseeing, (1) Hashiguiiwa (2) Shionomisaki Lighthouse (3) Muryoji (Maruyama Okyo, Nagasawa Rosetsu's bran picture is worth seeing.)
If you are staying at the former Kushimoto Royal Hotel, you should remove it for 3 nights and 4 days.
● Katsuura Onsen is a day trip, but there are many very good hot springs. All are flowing from the source. (1) Nassayama Onsen (excellent) (2) Kiyomonyu (3) Yuriyama Onsen and many recommendations.
For sightseeing, Nachi Taisha (the god is Nachi Falls) Nachi Taisha is said to be Kumano Sanzan, and there are three mountains at Shingu's Hayatama Taisha and Hongu's Hongu Taisha.
If you are staying at a hotel, my recommendation is "Umi no Hotel Ichinotaki", but it is an old hotel that has nothing but hot springs, but the hot springs are the best hot springs that flow directly from the source. Meals are not included. If you go to Katsuura, please eat tuna.
There are many delicious shops around Katsuura Station. My recommendation is to make a reservation for both "Hiro 𠮷" and "One wheel" for dinner. For lunch, we recommend "Takehara". If you would like to dine at the hotel, Manseiro is the place to go.
There are "Hotel Urashima" and "Nakanoshima" (the hot springs are circulating, but the scenery is nice), but if you stay in Katsuura, you can hang around in front of Katsuura station and have a footbath. We recommend that you have tuna at.
● I would like you to stay overnight at the main shrine (Yu no Mine) hot spring. Since it is in the mountains, there is no place to go outside to eat.
My regular inn is "Minshuku Yamane" (8,000 yen with half board), but the toilet is shared and old, but the hot spring is the same source as the hot spring. There is also an old-fashioned "Ryokan Azumaya", so if you are new to Azumaya, you should go for it.
Speaking of sightseeing, please come in at Tsuboyu. How about making hot spring eggs? If you want to visit, it's
Hongu Taisha. It is also a good idea to walk along the Kumano Kodo from Prince Shinshinmon to the main shrine.

1 night in Shirahama → 1 night in Katsuura → 1 night in Hongu (Yu no Mine) is recommended.
I have listed the recommendations without permission, but public transportation is very vulnerable. That is another good point. There is little traffic and we recommend renting a car for about 3 days from Shirahama Station. The traffic is light and the roads are wide except for Yunomine Onsen.

By train, it
takes about two and a half hours from Shin-Osaka to Shirahama by limited express Kuroshio.
If you want to take a reserved seat at this time, we recommend the seat on the left side when you return from the seat on the right side in the direction of travel.
The car body shakes quite a bit, but the view from the car window is the best.

Shin-Osaka Station → Shirahama Station (Shirahama sightseeing is by bus or taxi) Shirahama Station or Kise Line train movement → Katsuura Station (bus OR taxi such as Nachi) Katsuura Station to Shingu Station (train movement) From Shingu to Hongu is a bus movement. Please note that the number is small! It takes about an hour and a half.

column6:
unako-san I'm really impressed with the wonderfulness of this site, as I received kind and worried comments from everyone and responded politely each time. I think that you have already obtained enough information, but there are some concerns, so I will add it as an answer. We would like you to experience the splendor of Yakushima and visit it many times in the future, so please read it as a frank reference opinion, although it includes content that makes the already commented person feel bad.

First of all, the history of mountaineering is not clear, but I am confident in my physical strength because I have experienced a full marathon, and the couple have some experience in mountaineering? I will start with the conclusion, assuming that you have. I will explain the details of the reason later.

1) Yakushima has a lot of rain and is characterized by sudden changes in the weather, so be sure to bring rain gear, warm clothing, mountain climbing shoes, and a flashlight. Sneakers are out of the question.
2) Please take action from the perspective of protecting the World Heritage Sites of Yakushima. Please bring a portable toilet as a minimum etiquette. If it remains unused, please use it as equipment when the car is congested.
3) It is recommended to accompany an island guide. Either way, knowing the natural knowledge of Yakushima on the preceding course will double your benefits, including the next climb.

First of all, I would like to briefly describe my experience of commenting on this. Twenty years ago, I happened to have land on Yakushima with my friends, and every year I visit and enjoy day trekking with my husband and wife and friends. I have visited Mt. Miyanoura, Jomon cedar, Shiratani Unsuikyo, Kuromidake, Tatechudake, Janoguchi waterfall, Motchomudake, Ryujin cedar, etc. many times, including guidance from acquaintances. However, tickets are cheap in the seasons to go, June, August, October and December, and unfortunately I have no experience in March.

Therefore, the above reason is as follows.
1) Yakushima is a raised granite island with roots on a thin surface and trees growing on it. This is the reason why Yakusugi was born, but when it rains heavily on the mountains, it does not penetrate the ground sufficiently and flows into the sea at once. Today's muddy stream will be a beautiful murmuring tomorrow. The mountain roads are flooded with water, and rivers that can be crossed cannot be crossed due to flooding. Even if it is sunny at Nagata Beach, the downpour is rough at Miyanoura. Since the schedule is tight, you should be prepared for rain climbing first and think that you are lucky if you do not use rain gear. If it's sunny, please insist that it's Haruo.
2) I am familiar with the various islands that are being developed to protect the World Heritage Sites. We ask climbers to cooperate in various places, so please agree. Cooperation fee (mountain entry, toilet), take-out of garbage, simple toilet (must bring a portable toilet), etc.
3) We hope that you will not only go through the Jomon cedar course, but also enjoy the wonderful nature of Yakushima. Yakushima is one of the world's leading treasure trove of moss and is said to have 600 types. If you can afford it, ask for a guide, who will explain the name of the moss and the natural wonders of Yakushima with a number of Yakusugi. Just by going back and forth to see Jomon cedar, you have abandoned its value. I think that a simple round-trip journey can be done in about 8 hours, but it is recommended that you spend more time observing the surroundings of the mountain trail while trekking.

Lastly, as I have experienced several times, it is better to have a cable tie on hand when using old hiking boots. Recently, the number of cases where the soles of shoes have come off and abandoned during mountain climbing is increasing.

It's been a long time, but it would be great if you could climb Yakushima and enjoy the mild weather and even encounter the snowy landscape. Finally, I pray that Mr. and Mrs. Unako will enjoy climbing Yakushima, which will be a memorial.

In addition, I will describe it in the reference URL if you refer to the travel report that I went to Taikoiwa with my 6-year-old grandson this December.

On my way home, I came back from the darkness because I was sick and late. Fortunately, I had a flashlight, so I managed to illuminate my feet. I hope this isn't the case, but it's a good idea to bring a small headlight or flashlight just in case.

And I think there was a place to climb the slope along the rope on the way. I think it's a good idea to bring work gloves or gloves.

I think there is still time to cool down in March. If it is heavy, it will be a burden, so I think it is good to bring something that can be light and warm. It's heavy, but I think it's a good idea to bring a little more drinking water. There were some places where I could supply water, but I remember being thirsty more than I expected and having trouble in the field.

Then please be careful.

I went to Yakushima twice, the first time to climb Jomon cedar, and the second time to Mt. Miyanoura and Shiratani Unsuikyo (drum rock). I usually climb mountains.

Jomon cedar mountain climbing is a mountain trail beyond the trolley road, and it is long.
I think trekking shoes (ankle-length shoes, light climbing shoes) are better than sneakers because they have a lot of water and are slippery.

Although I had stock, I forgot to use it at the inn (laugh)
I think that if you are not familiar with stock, your arm will get tired just by having it, but on the other hand, it will come in handy when you get tired on the descent. increase. I think it's safe to have one foldable wand. If you don't mind carrying it around (if it's attached to your backpack), you can even have two stocks.

When climbing Jomon cedar, it seems that you don't have much time to unload your luggage and take a break (the break is about 5 minutes while standing), so if you put candy and chocolate in a place where you can easily take them out, put them in your waist belt pocket, etc. Convenient!

I want to go to Yakushima again! Enjoy yourself.

good evening.

I can't answer because I don't stay at Kanpo no Yado, but I often go to Kyushu because I have friends in Amakusa, and I'm wandering around in Kyushu, so there are places where I went from Aso to Hita.

From the north side of Aso, take Route 212 and pass Oguni Town to Hita. It's hard to get a sense of distance, but if you only use numbers, you can find the distance and time by searching for Hita from Kumamoto Airport using the Google Maps route guide (the route of the map app on your smartphone).
It's less than two hours, but it takes a little longer because you'll know the detours, such as Daikanbo, Oguni Town, Nabegataki, where you can go to the back of the waterfall, and a strange roadside station. I'm sorry.
By the way, Oguni Town has Kurokawa Onsen. Is it possible to stop by with a drop-in hot water?

The route from Kumamoto prefecture to Oita prefecture is over the mountains, but it is a wonderful landscape.

Another route is famous for the Yamanami Highway. On a sunny day around October, the green shines and is beautiful.

There is a Sapporo beer factory in Hita. The driver can only drink non-alcoholic drinks, but I personally felt that I didn't have to stop by.

In November, there is a place famous for autumn leaves called Yabakei, which is located east of Hita. Yufuin is located south of there, and you can also return to Aso via the Yamanami Highway.

There is a sweets shop called She Tani on the Yamanami Highway's Semoto Kogen, but if it's sunny, the view is nice, so why not stop by for a break?

Mt. Aso in autumn is covered with Japanese pampas grass, and in the evening it becomes a golden world.

In Kitakyushu, the construction of the station building where Moji Station is located has been completed, the historic station building has been revived, there is Mojiko Retro, and there is a humanitarian tunnel that you can walk across the Moji Strait.

It seems that there are many eel shops that think that Yanagawa is only Yanagawa descent, Yanagawa nabe, and loach.

Kyushu is a good place, so please enjoy it.

I'm from Southern Kyushu.
From the answers of other people, I think that the next morning has already been selected, but I will
add a little information in the direction of approval, so please refer to it if you like.

As you know, Takachiho Gorge is surrounded by high rock walls that rise vertically, but the
sun shines into this deep and narrow valley for a short time in the morning.
If the weather is good and the amount of water in the waterfall is large, the contrast of the light that reflects off the splashes and the gradation of the water surface will be
very beautiful, and you will be able to encounter a more fantastic landscape.
If Takachiho Gorge is one of the main trips, you may want to aim for the time zone as well.

Aso also has many spectacular views and attractions that are comparable to Takachiho Gorge, so
why not incorporate it into your itinerary?

I hope it will be a memorable trip!
column7: From Kumamoto Castle to Takachiho Gorge

column6:
Hello.

A long time ago, I rented a car in Karashima-cho, which is close to Kumamoto Castle in Kumamoto City, and went to Takachiho at once without any traffic jams and without a break.

At that time, it took almost two hours to reach the "Tunnel Station", which is close to the center of Takachiho, so I think it will take two hours at the earliest to reach the boat stop in Takachiho Gorge.

However, I'm a little worried about Sunday, May, which is the holiday season.

If you want to go to Takachiho from Kumamoto city, you can go via the Aso area, which has a good view, or you can take the monotonous national highway No. 445-218 (there is a tourist attraction, Tsujun Bridge).

On a sunny Sunday, depending on the time of day, if you go via the Aso area, the roads from Kumamoto city to the entrance of the Aso area will be crowded, so the arrival time of Takachiho will differ depending on the congestion situation ( I think it will be late).

If you go via the Aso area, you can enjoy the magnificent scenery around Aso, and the Minamiaso area, which is a stopover, has a partly Swiss-like scenery, which is really good.

Maybe I'll go to the Aso area the day after Takachiho, but if I'm planning to go to the Aso area the next day, I think it's less time consuming to go on National Routes 445-218, which isn't too crowded. ..
column7: From Kumamoto Castle to Takachiho Gorge

it is just a relief. The scenery on a sunny day is nice, but when it rains, it gets foggy immediately.

This is a detour route when the fog is deep, but if you go to Taketa, take the coastline of Route 10 from Beppu toward Nishi-Oita, pass by the
Oita IC, and go to Notsuharu-Taketa. (Yufuin can be reached from Nishi-Oita via No. 210 via Sakuma)

Ajimu should go from Beppu along the coast of Route 10 from Hiji to Ajimu. (There is less thick fog than high speed)
It's a great trip, so I hope it's sunny.

column7: 5 days around Shikoku with a rental car

column6:
It's my first time in Shikoku, and if it's 4 nights and 5 days, I'd like to go around the coast without being too greedy. I think it feels good to go around sightseeing spots near your accommodation.
The reason is that it takes a long time to move and it is not possible to make it in time for dinner, and it is easy to get tired after lunch and fall asleep on a hot summer drive.
(The highway development is delayed in the southeastern half, and it is difficult to hurry even if the road is

open .) Given that premise, I think that the reverse direction is better than the order of Kagawa → Ehime → Kochi → Tokushima. ..
That is, the first night is around Tokushima City. The second night around Cape Muroto is around Kochi City. The third night is around Shimanto City, Cape Ashizuri, and Sukumo. The 4th night is a night around Matsuyama City such as Dogo Onsen.
There is also a highway on the last day, so even if you stop by the Besshi Copper Mine site, I think you have time to eat Sanuki udon around Takamatsu.
If you have a strong desire to take a picture of the sunset at Chichibugahama or Shimonada Station in Ehime, minimize the area around Cape Ashizuri and Yadoge and use the highway for the third night around Matsuyama City such as Dogo Onsen. Would be good. I want to avoid moving after sunset.

By turning in the opposite direction, you can see the sea better because you drive in the lane along the shore, and in the morning you run mainly westward and northward with the sun behind, so you can see the scenery of the forward rays and it is not dazzling even in the middle of summer. I have. There are few places on the cliff where you have a hard time passing by oncoming vehicles. (Although it faces east on the morning of the last day, it is mainly high speed, not the coast.)

"This is the only place you should go" depends on your interests.
Nature is abundant such as the cape and the Shimanto River, and history lovers such as Kochi Castle and the cityscape of Uchiko cannot miss it. Focusing on your favorite themes such as hot springs, literature, temples and shrines, and industrial heritage, and (because it is the end of the rainy season), a B plan on a rainy day is also essential.

"Food" is delicious in season, so it is recommended that you choose seasonal seafood and mountain food (if you don't know, ask for recommendations) at that time (according to your budget).

As for souvenirs, I personally like Yuzu. (Products from Umaji Village, Kochi Prefecture, local confectionery tarts from Matsuyama City, etc.)

column6:
It's nice to visit the hot springs for 4 nights and 5 days. I used to climb mountains, but for the last 15 years or so, I've lost my strength, so I've been going around the hot springs in the mountains.
The quality and environment of the hot springs, the remoteness of the inn and one-day bathing (my favorite) and the one-house inn vary from person to person, so please check carefully and choose the one you like.

First of all, it is "Second Tomei", but after opening, it is called "Shin Tomei".

In the "Metropolitan area → Second Tomei Expressway (scheduled to arrive in Aichi Prefecture in the evening, no plans to stop by except for lunch breaks on the way)", how about taking a bath at Umegashima Onsen, the most upstream of the Abe River?
(It's a place where you don't have many chances to go because it's clogged up, but from Shin-Tomei, it's closer than from Tomei.)

If you go via the Abo Tunnel, you can go to Hirayu Onsen for a day trip to Hirayu Onsen. If you're staying overnight, you can go to Sakamaki Onsen Ryokan, or if you want to stay a little further away, you can go to Okuhida Garden Hotel Yakedake. (Speaking of greed, Fukuji Onsen "Yumoto Choza" and Shin-Hotaka Onsen "Shinzanso", etc.)

If you go via the Hokuriku Expressway,
why not visit the hot springs from Unazuki Onsen by trolley train?
Kurobe Gorge, "Kuronagi Onsen Ryokan" (the source of Unazuki Onsen) with a real large open-air bath, and "Meiken Onsen", which is small.

Also, if you are looking for Sakura Onsen "Ryuunso", which is unfamiliar to people in the Tokyo metropolitan area recommended by Arara, we recommend the immediate Yakeyama Onsen "Seifukan". The difference from Sakura Onsen is that it springs naturally, but we recommend the hinoki cypress open-air, which has a slightly smaller amount of ingredients due to heating, but has a splendid flea mark on the beam. If you want to focus on the quality of the spring, try Sakura Onsen.

I also like Tsubame Onsen. If you walk a little, there is also a free mixed bathing open-air bath.
I think the morning sun looks good (if the direction of sunrise is bad, you can climb a little or drive to Shin-Akakura Onsen).

In addition, Jigokudani Onsen "Korakukan" is a little over 20 minutes on the mountain road from the free parking lot of Kambayashi Ski Resort (only the first climb), but if you are on the back of the Shibu Onsen side, you can walk on the forest road from the toll parking lot that is closed to vehicles. I think it will arrive within 10 minutes.
http://www.jigokudanionsen.com/about/#Access I like the

route, but if I'm a student, I think it's a course that starts counterclockwise from the Sea of Japan side where there are few people and returns with the Shin Tomei Expressway.

column6:
Hammer Clavier Nice to meet you!
I love Hakone, so please enjoy the goodness of Hakone!

The flow is like
staying in Yugawara → sightseeing in Hakone → staying in Hakone Yumoto
.
When was I, but will be a prelude to that
move from Yugawara in one morning to Hakone Yumoto, leave your luggage
↓
climbing railway to Gora
↓
Gora from the cable car to Sounzan
↓
Sounzan from to Owakudani in ropeway
↓
Owakudani Take the ropeway to Sounzan
↓ Take the
Ashinoko Pleasure Boat to Moto Hakone (or Hakone Town)
↓ Take the
bus to Hakone Yumoto (U-turn on the same route is also possible if you have time)

.
With this, you can see the typical scenery of Hakone, and you
have just moved, but it is not a big deal in terms of distance & the scenery along the way is good, so it is a route that can be said to be a royal road.
It's an image of sightseeing in between.
Tourist attractions on this route include Gora Park, The Hakone Open Air Museum in front of Gora Station, Owakudani, and Hakone Shrine in Motohakone.
There are various museums in Hakone, and the transportation network is well maintained, so
if you have something you like, you can cut somewhere and head to it.
I like the Pola Museum of Art and the Okada Museum of Art in Hakone, so
If the weather is not good on the day, I think I should cut the Hakone Open Air Museum and use either of these.

Enjoy Hakone's holiday ♪

column6:
I have had friends since I was a student, so I visited Hirosaki many times, including the cherry blossom season and the apple blossom season. I like the historical cityscape.

In autumn, you can catch apples, the apple pie is delicious, and you can see Mt. Iwaki and Mt. Hakkoda, so I recommend it.

I'm not in the tourist site, but if you are interested in buildings and art, I'm telling my friends to come and see it, but I haven't been to Corona yet,
but "Hirosaki Museum of Contemporary Art " opened last year. The "Warehouse Museum" reference URL seems to be recommended.

When visiting Hirosaki Castle and Western-style buildings, you have to park your bicycle at the bicycle parking lot and return to it, so you may consider moving by bus from the station to Hirosaki Castle.
I don't mind walking, so I walk from the station that is biased to the east of the city to Hirosaki Castle while looking at the cityscape.
It was an impression of a cultural cityscape with many bookstores.

Sightseeing spots are concentrated around Hirosaki Castle and on the east side of the castle. Hirosaki Castle Park itself is also quite large.
In that sense, I think that staying at a hotel in the center of the city between the station and the castle is more emotional in the morning and evening walks (Western-style building illumination, etc.) than staying at the hotel in front of the station. ..

I like the order in which I go around, but when I'm tired of walking, I think it's better to sit down and have an apple pie than to take it home. It's good to eat and compare.

column6:
To Karumegi-san I

think Hirosaki has probably been there five times.
First of all, you should be able to go to places other than Apple Park in time. Only Angelique is a little far from other tourist destinations.
In my opinion, on the first day, I rented an electric bicycle at the tourist information center in front of the station, (1) Angelique, (2) Neputa Village, (3) Hirosaki Castle (not only the exterior but also the castle tower, moat, and stone wall), and (4) Municipal Tourist Center. Visit. Then return the bicycle to the Municipal Tourist Center or the tourist information center in front of the station.
On the second day, take a bus to the Municipal Tourist Center and walk to (1) Former Hirosaki Municipal Library, (2) Sansha Exhibition Hall, (3) Tooku Gijuku Foreign Teachers' Hall (tea), (4) Fujita Memorial Garden and Taisho Roman Tea Room (tea), (5) Aomori Bank Memorial Museum and Hirosaki Church of the Japanese Christian Church. Next, ⑥ about 800m (walk or taxi) to the five-storied pagoda, ⑦ about 1.2km (walk or taxi) to the former Hirosaki Kaikousha (closed until September 26), ⑧ about 1.3km (walk or taxi) to the hotel. .. I think it's a good idea to rent an electric bicycle at the Municipal Tourist Center and return it at the tourist information center in front of the station.

For dinner, we recommend the "Creative Local Cuisine Kikufuji Main Store" or the "Local Cuisine Dining Hibiki" where you can dine while listening to the Tsugaru Shamisen at the Hirosaki Park Hotel.

Please note that the holidays and business hours have changed due to the influence of Corona.

First, my travel history in Shimane.

I didn't use Tamatsukuri Onsen last year, but around 2015, I stayed at Tamatsukuri Onsen Ryotei Yamanoi for one night and the other night was from Iwami Ginzan. I went around Izumo Taisha Shrine and Iwami Ginzan. This trip is by private car.

If you read your worries from the question, we will understand and describe them as follows.

1. How about Tamatsukuri Onsen as a place to stay for 3 consecutive nights in Shimane sightseeing? Is there any other hot spring resort that is convenient for sightseeing?
2. What is the transportation access from Tamatsukuri Onsen to Izumo Taisha? Is a day trip possible?
3. Sightseeing is at Izumo Taisha Shrine, Matsue Castle. I wish I could go to Lake Shinji.

About 1.
I stayed at an inn that was different for two nights. On the other hand, if you stay for 3 nights, you can stay for consecutive nights, and I think it is possible to travel only by public transportation.
Tamatsukuri Onsen is really convenient in Matsue city. surprised.
I also considered it so that everyone would recommend Shinjiko Onsen.
However, due to the check-in time, I couldn't find a place to eat, so it was a plan.
If you don't go to downtown Matsue, there aren't many restaurants other than hotels. (A store where it is difficult to make a reservation even if there is one ...)

2.
Of course, it is an area where you can make a day trip!

You can also see the timetable at the URL.
https://www.ichibata.co.jp/t-izumo/shuttle/izumo.html
By the way, the timetable on August 26th departs Tamatsukuri Onsen at 8:15 and arrives at Izumo Taisha at 9:30.
Depart Izumo Taisha at 14:45 and arrive at Tamatsukuri Onsen at 16:13. It is one round trip.

After that, take the San-in Main Line to Izumo City Station, and then take the
Ichibata Densha Kitamatsue Line to Kawato Station. At Kawato Station, change to the Ichibata Electric Railway Taisha Line and Izumo Taisha Station.

timing, but the difference between the first and the second is only about 10 minutes. It is the bus that does not walk. The cost is about the same.

I think it's okay because the route is downhill, aiming for Izumo Taisha Station through the approach road lined with souvenir shops.

About 3. As

you may know Lake Shinji, there are cruise ships from Matsue city.
http://hakuchougo.jp/
Also, I'm not sure how you think about how to enjoy Lake Shinji, but Ichibata Electric Railway Kitamatsue Line is quite along the lake, so if you move during the day, you can enjoy it with your eyes.
The sunset is famous from the Shimane Art Museum and along Lake Shinji in front of the Matsue Police Station.

There seems to be a fishing experience, but I'm not interested so I don't know. sorry.

Izumo Taisha also visits in the official order of worship, receives prayers, and receives a red stamp. If you do a full course, such as sightseeing in Hinomisaki, visiting Hinomisaki Shrine, and visiting the Shimane Prefectural Museum of Ancient Izumo History, it will be quite difficult even for one day. Is it finally from morning till night?

From here on, I think that there are roughly 5 patterns of what you see in Shimane tourism, at my own discretion.
1. Sightseeing centered on gods such as Izumo Taisha
2. Sightseeing centered on history and landscape, art
3.1. And 2. Sightseeing that has a lot of movement but is wide and shallow

I feel that the information written by Mr. Yuki is one of 1-3.
When I stayed for two nights and three days, I went sightseeing in pattern 3, and when I stayed at Tamatsukuri Onsen, I went sightseeing in pattern 4.

The first day seems to be traveling and spending time in Okayama city, so I think Shimane sightseeing will be the same two nights and three days as I did last year.
However, if you stay for 3 consecutive nights, it will take 2 to 3 hours for a total of round trips every day, so I think it is better to proceed with the timetable in the plan.

column6:
Nice to meet you. Posting to this site has been suspended for many years, but Shimanami and Tobishima Kaido are my favorite spots, so I will answer.
It may have already been checked, but on Ikuchi Island, Kosanji Temple, which is close to Guest House NEST, is the most recommended. In the precincts, there is also "The Hill of Hope", the best SNS spot on the Shimanami Kaido.

Kosanji is a temple theme park, and is packed with buildings that faithfully reproduce famous temples and shrines nationwide, such as Nikko Toshogu Yomei Gate, Byodo-in Temple, and Ginkakuji Temple.
The 350m-long artificial cave "Senbutsu-do Jigokukyo" is cool in summer and warm in winter. It looks like a limestone cave because it is dug up to 15m underground.
The Hill of Hope is a large sculptured garden made of 3,000 tons of white marble, reminiscent of the Greek island of Santorini.

Omishima is home to Oyamazumi Shrine, the most powerful spot on the Shimanami Kaido, and the national treasures of the Treasure Hall are worth a visit. It is said that you can live longer and be happy when you go through the "Gomon of the Living Tree".

Like Mahina, I recommend Okunoshima, which is a regular boat from Sakariko on Omishima. Nearly 1,000 wild rabbits, one of the best in the world, inhabit and come to you when you show them food. The bait used to be sold at the Sheng Port Office for 100 yen at an unmanned sales office in Honesty Box, but it is safer to bring it with you just in case. However, only Okunoshima guests can bring their bicycles to the island. The island is small so you can walk around. There is no private house.

You can get a walking map at the visitor center on the island. The map shows a huge poisonous gas storage and turret traces during the war, but the concrete air raid shelter that descends on the underground stairs at the Tsukiyama-style part opposite the visitor center entrance is thrilling. However, you will need a flashlight.
You can eat at the former national dormitory called "Kyukamura Okunoshima".
If you have a car, you can enjoy the panorama at the highest observatory on each island, but there are many scenic spots along the coast, so please enjoy it.
https://www.travel.co.jp/guide/article/40737/

column6:
Even if you say "Hiroshima," Hiroshima Prefecture is the 11th largest in Japan with 8,479 square kilometers, so it depends on where you want to go.
If your destination is in Hiroshima City or the surrounding area (Atomic Bomb Dome, Peace Memorial Park, Miyajima, Itsukushima Shrine), using the Hiroden (road train and Miyajima Line) will save you time and cost. It is also advantageous in terms of. It is more convenient to use JR or bus for Kintaikyo Bridge in Iwakuni City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, which is the neighboring prefecture. You can drive to the Yamato Museum in Kure, but you may not have to worry about parking if you use the Kure Line, Hiroden Bus, or JR Bus Claire Line. On the other hand, if you want to go to the Setouchi Shimanami Kaido, renting a car is more advantageous. If you want to take a walk in Onomichi, it is more convenient to use JR.
By the way, Hiroshima and Fukuyama are quite far apart, about 23 minutes by Shinkansen and about 130 minutes by Sanyo Main Line, so I think it's best to plan only.

I often drive to Kuratake, but it takes about 30 minutes from Hondo to the traffic light of No. 266, which is on the road to Kuratake Shrine. It takes about 30 minutes from the signal to Kuratake Shrine. I was thinking of going on a clear day because it was always hazy, but I went there because the sky became clear in February, but of course it was a narrow road. There are few oncoming vehicles. Although it was a curve, there were places where there was no curve mirror, so I ran slowly and slowly. This lasts for about 30 minutes, so I'm very tired mentally, it was like that.
https://4travel.jp/travelogue/11678556
As an aside, there is a former pachinko parlor in Kuratake where members of the band WANIMA were practicing the band. Who is he looking inside every time he passes in front of him?

The direction of the Amakusa Shiro Museum is also different. It is in front of a product building called Sanpar in Oyano near Kumamoto from Hondo, but the Rapid Amakusa stops at this Sanpar, so get off there and take a tour to the next Rapid Amakusa. It can also be called a ride. However, as I wrote earlier, the Rapid Amakusa train has only one pace per hour, and the time has changed a little due to the reduced number of flights, so if you do this, you will not have time to go to other places. However, even if you rent a car, the direction is different, so I don't think you can take the time.
This Oyano. I think the timing of the signal is bad, but weekends and holidays are a point of congestion. It wasn't so much now, but on weekends and holidays, it's a good idea to check the traffic jam information.

After crossing the No. 1 bridge and leaving Amakusa, the rapid train Amakusa also stops here, but Misumi West Port is also a World Heritage Site. It's calming down, but it was crowded when it became a World Heritage Site.

It's about 20 minutes from Kumamoto Airport to Amakusa Airport by Mizoka-chan, so it's very close. However, the drawback is that the fare is high. .. .. If you go home with Mizoka-chan, you'll arrive in Itami at noon, so it's okay to go early, but it's too expensive to use. ..
If you want to get more freedom, you may want to rent a car from Kumamoto city or Misumi station. However, for example, it takes less than 2 hours from Kumamoto Station to Hondo Bus Center. Misumi Station also takes about 1 hour by regular train from Kumamoto Station, about 40 minutes by train A for sightseeing limited express, and about 1 hour by car from Misumi Station to Hondo Bus Center. Of course, there are no trains, so it is not absolutely recommended because it is necessary to set the time here as well. I wrote it as one of the choices.

The guideline for the time by car is Kumamoto Station-Triangle Station-Hondo-Ushibuka, which takes 1 hour each. There is a road under construction on the Hondoko side. If this can be done, it seems that the distance between Kumamoto and Amakusa will be shortened by about 30 minutes, but there is still more.

It's a nice place, so if you can change it, I think the best thing is to stay overnight in Amakusa for more fun.

Excuse me for a long time.

Please enjoy yourself ~

Imabari Towel Museum. There is also a tour corner, so it's not possible to take a quick look.
Whirlpools in the Kurushima Strait. July 23-26 is the spring tide. In addition to whirlpools, you can also see tankers as they pass near the shipyard. Since it is a strait, you may be able to see cruise ships if the timing is right.

Kochi is a karst plateau, Niyodo Blue. On a hot day, Ryuga Cave can be cool, but as the name suggests, the last tough slope is the stairs.

Tokushima is Kazura Bridge and Oku Iya's Double Kazura Bridge. It's a suspension bridge, so you don't have to go if you're not good at it. It is a thrilling suspension bridge because it is squeaky and there are quite a few gaps between the bridge boards.
The Great Bodhisattva Pass in Anan Town. It is a so-called coffee shop. At first glance, it looks like a ruin, but it's a self-built and tasteful building.

You can check the route, distance, and required time of each destination with the route of the map application (for example, Google Maps) on your smartphone or PC, so please check those points you care about and make a schedule. If you pack too much, you will not be able to turn around, so moderately.

You can also check sightseeing points on Google Maps, so please try to find the place you are interested in.

Be careful and have a fun trip.

I live in the Tokyo metropolitan area and have never traveled from Osaka to Nikko Toshogu, but I hope you find it helpful.

＞＞ It seems difficult to change buses and trains from Haneda Airport.

The flight from Osaka will be faster than the Shinkansen, but considering the security passage, it will save less time than walking by transfer.
Buses from Haneda Airport are out of the question, but I think that
trains usually connect to the Shinkansen via Keihin Kyuko or Monorail, as well as from Keihin Kyuko to Tobu Sky Tree Line / Nikko via Toei Subway Oshiage.
However, it is not recommended to take a sufficient transfer time to buy a reserved-seat ticket or waste a lot of transfers because there will be many delays in flights.

We recommend connecting at Tokyo Station on the Tokaido Shinkansen and Tohoku Shinkansen and getting off at Utsunomiya Station. If the bus time for Nikko Toshogu is right, it will be easier to get to Toshogu directly with one bus.

Alternatively, change to JR Nikko Line from Utsunomiya Station to JR Nikko Station, then take a bus to Toshogu.
(If you are accustomed to traveling and the bus time is right, you can get off at Shimoimaichi Station on the way and catch the bus for Toshogu.)

column6:
It's Otemachi, but the takeaway at the Palace Hotel is delicious.

I used the Estelle box of Alain Ducasse's 1-Michelin French "Ester" in the hotel.
The main course, salad, bread, etc. are set so that you can eat it as it is without warming it.
It's a simple dish, but the dressing and sauce complemented the taste of the ingredients, and it tasted like a stone.
https://www.palacehoteltokyo.com/restaurants-bars/takeout/ At the

Palace Hotel, we have also taken out a party box (starter set). Finger food is perfect for a wine snack.
Each one is small, but when two people ate it, it was quite hungry.

Also, "My French" has opened a takeout specialty store diagonally in front of Kabukiza Theater in Higashi-Ginza. https://www.oreno.co.jp/restaurants/grandmarket
Bread, salads, roasted meat, etc. are available. I've been in the store but I didn't buy it so I can't comment on the taste, but it's very busy.

For Japanese food, I sometimes use the lunch box of Mr. Mitomoi in the basement of Matsuya Ginza.
It's a branch of a caterer in Kyoto, so it's seasoned elegantly.

column6:
When it comes to traveling to 4 prefectures in 5 days, it seems better to think about each staying time a little shorter.

There are many places I would like to recommend in each prefecture, but if a woman in her twenties visits for the first time
・ In Kochi, Hirome Market, Kochi Castle, Katsurahama, Shimanto River, Yasui Valley
/ Kagawa, Udon Shop tour, Marugame Castle, Kochi Castle, Kuribayashi Park, Kinbirayama
/ Ehime, Uwajima Castle, Dogo Onsen, Matsuyama Castle, Bochan Train, Qingdao, Towel Museum ICHIHIRO
/ Tokushima, Naruto Whirlpool, Otsuka International Museum, Meishan Is it around the ropeway, Awa Odori Kaikan, and the Aizumi Town History Museum "Ai no Yakata" where you can experience dyeing
?
However, please be sure to consider the travel time to each prefecture. Even though there is a highway, it is quite wide.



Famous foods are

Tokushima: Tai, Tokushima ramen, buckwheat rice soup, fish cutlet
Kagawa: Udon, chicken with bones, octopus rice, simmered rice cake with bean paste, Kozushima's Tenobe Somen
Kochi: Katsuo, Que, Sake thief・ Nabeyaki Ramen ・ Udon ・ Naruko Don ・ Pot plate dish ・ Shimizu mackerel ・ Whale's firm pot ・ Koumeshi ・ Egani ・ Aosa no Tempura
Ehime: Uwashima's sashimi ・ Sashimi noodles ・ Tsurunoko ・ Jakoten・ Iyo Satsuma ・Examples include moburi rice, fluffy udon noodles, grilled pork egg rice, horaku-yaki, imabari yakitori, Osu croquette, Imabari ramen, and swordfish chirimen bowl

.
There are usually good places to buy special products, fresh vegetables, fruits, and fish at roadside stations, so if you're traveling by car, that's the aim.
